homepage.siteDescription: OpenTechSchool is a movement aiming to offer free tech education.

masthead.title: Free tech education
masthead.subtitle: OpenTechSchool is a movement aiming to offer free tech education.

otsInitiative.title: The OTS initiative
otsInitiative.description: OpenTechSchool is a movement aiming to offer free tech education.
otsInitiative.description2:
Volunteers all around Europe organizing welcoming and inclusive code learnings happenings with real people in the real world. 
 We offer free tech workshops with learning material and in-person learning support. 
 People of all genders, backgrounds, levels, ages come together to learn, to coach or to organize in a cozy and including space provided for hands-on learning.

otsCommunity.title: Your local community
otsCommunity.description: Meet other learners at weekly meetups in your city. Bring your projects, questions and positive attitude. Get the chance to meet people with different experience levels and backgrounds. This is the place to get support, learn together and connect.

learner.title: Learner
learner.description: If you are looking to learn coding yourself, you probably want to find out more about the community and when the next meetup takes place near you.

support.title: Supporter
support.description: If you like what OTS is doing, there are multiple ways to support the initiative. Maybe you have a space to offer or want to sponsor the next event.

coach.title: Volunteer
coach.description: If you feel like donating some of your time and knowledge, our chapters always need passionate coaches and organizers for the events.

events.title: At our events
events.description: The best way to get in touch with the community is at our events. Just come by, feel the vibe and speak to one of the organizers. Nice to meet you!

slack.title: Online chat
slack.description: We are using Slack to connect and share information beyond the events. Say hi in the #general channel or find the one for your city.

email.title: Email
email.description: Contact us directly if you have a general question and the above options are not working for you. We love to hear from you, but remember we are all volunteers and might need some time to reply.

history.title: History
history.description: OTS was born in April of 2012 in Berlin. The first local RailsGirls event — a free tech workshop with freshly created learning materials dedicated to an audience of women of all ages and backgrounds during a both thrilling and cosy weekend — had just taken place, and had created much admiration and enthusiasm in its wake.
history.description2: Why not expand the concept to all tech topics people might possibly want to learn and open the events to an audience of all genders and experience levels? The challenge couldn’t be greater. Since then, hundreds of people have joined OTS as coaches, learners, organizers, and sponsors, in Berlin, Leipzig, and soon: even in more new cities (yours!).

explanation.title: What is OpenTechSchool?
explanation.description: OpenTechSchool is a movement aiming to offer free tech education. Our events are open to technology enthusiasts of all genders, backgrounds, and experience levels, willing to coach or learn in a friendly environment. Our learning materials are shared and collectively improved by the online community and anyone is welcome to use it to organize new OTS chapters anywhere in the world.

coreValue.title: Core values
coreValue.description: OpenTechSchool is best described through our core values.

openness.title: Openess
openness.shortDescription: All OTS discussions, training materials, and blueprints are openly accessible through our website
openness.description: All OTS discussions, training materials, and blueprints are openly accessible through our website so that anyone can find them and contribute to their development. Furthermore, for OTS, openness also means sharing: our coaches share their skills and time, and our learners share their own knowledge with the community, both by presenting their achievements during the beginners meetup and by later becoming coaches themselves.

empowerment.title: Empowerment
empowerment.shortDescription: Encouraging people to coach, whatever their skill or experience level, lets them see how rewarding and valuable teaching others is.
empowerment.description: Empowerment is something which we hope to provide everyone involved. Encouraging people to coach, whatever their skill or experience level, lets them see how rewarding and valuable teaching others is. By encouraging learners to become coaches themselves, we hope to create a sustainable movement of skilled and confident individuals who are eager to help others. Leaving the framework of workshop organization open to adaptation is done to empower others, providing a framework for them to rally their own communities and to organize similar initiatives.

handsOn.title: Hands-on learning
handsOn.shortDescription: We believe the best way to learn is by doing it hands-on, and feel that visible progress is the best motivation to continue learning.
handsOn.description: We believe the best way to learn is by doing it hands-on, and feel that visible progress is the best motivation to continue learning. That is why our workshops are focused on practical exercises and provide a hands-on learning experience. We bring people together to learn in small groups, supported by coaches who keep an eye on individual progress. Our workshops aim to reach a certain goal of the learning process while also providing a roadmap on how to continue afterwards.

welcoming.title: Welcoming learning environment
welcoming.shortDescription: We aim to provide a safe learning environment in which no one feels shy asking any question.
welcoming.description: We aim to provide a safe learning environment in which no one feels shy asking any question. Teaching only 3-4 people at a time, coaches can move at the pace most suited for their group, rather than moving on too quickly. Learners will be encouraged to share their progress, with the goal of solidifying their knowledge and helping them overcome any fears of speaking in front of others.

transparency.title: Transparency
transparency.shortDescription: OTS is an open, transparent movement with which we want to encourage others to create similar or related projects in their own cities.
transparency.description: OTS is an open, transparent movement with which we want to encourage others to create similar or related projects in their own cities. We hope to inspire you with our successes and let you learn from our mistakes, as well as develop a strong support network for those new to coding, giving them a chance to learn and go on to teach others.

nonProfit.title: Not for Profit
nonProfit.shortDescription: Coaches and team members donate their personal time for the greater good of the community and the learners.
nonProfit.description: We strongly believe that, in order for education to work, the learner needs to have the best learning experience possible. In order to achieve that, coaches and team members donate their personal time for the greater good of the community and the learners. It is only with this value as your main goal that you can create the experience needed to encourage learners to continue. If you'd do that for your personal gain the quality would simply suffer.
nonProfit.description2: That is why we run OpenTechSchool as a non-profit and operate on the lowest costs possible. Most workshops are run at no cost and are self-organised by the local communities. And while company sponsorship is welcome and makes events and parties more comfortable, it is not required to fund the day-to-day business of OTS, nor will it ever govern the way OTS functions.

policy.title: Our Licensing Policy
policy.description: In correspondence with our values we release all learning materials, blueprints and any other kind of content under the
policy.description2: As long as you attribute the work to OpenTechSchool (usually by mentioning such and providing the link to the original material) and share it under the same licence again, you are free to use, share, copy and modify it - even in a commercial context.

foundation.title: Foundation
foundation.description: The OpenTechSchool e.V. has officially been established January 5th, 2013. As of March 25th, 2013 it is officially registered as a "gemeinütziger e.V." — a non-profit foundation under German law. The main objective of creating the OpenTechSchool e.V. was to have a legal entity to help with sponsoring and structural things. Generally the foundations goal is to provide any kinds of service and help to nurture the OpenTechSchool movement all over the globe.
foundation.representedByBoard: The foundation is represented by its board:
foundation.contactTheBoard: To contact the board send an email at

membership.title: Membership
membership.description1: By becoming a member of the foundation you're actively supporting the community with your membership fees. You also get to vote for the board members and what we spend money on. We meet at least every two years for a general assembly.
membership.description2: The membership fee is 24€ per year (2€ per month). Currently, the money is mostly spent on operational costs such as meetup.com fees.
membership.agree: Please remember, by signing up, you agree to our

community.description: The OTS community is a group of tech-enthusiast, that like to learn and teach coding in a friendly environment.
community.description2: Tired of learning by yourself? We offer free local meetups, where learners with different experience levels can join, exchange knowledge, coach and motivate each other.
community.readCommunityValues: Read more about our community values

learner.title: Learner
learner.description: If you are looking to learn coding yourself, you probably want to find out more about the community and when the next meetup takes place near you.

coach.title: Coach
coach.description: If you can donate some of your time and knowledge to support your local chapter and you love to teach or coach other learners this job is for you.

organizer.title: Organizer
organizer.description: If you like to support the community in your city and love to organize events or meetups. We always need passionate organizers as part of the community.

formats.title: Formats
formats.description: If you got started with programming and would like to strengthen your skills or you are just curious what code is all about, the OpenTechSchool events are the best way to meet learners of all genders and experience levels.
formats.description2: OpenTechSchool also acts as a lab to experiement with new and interesting tech learning formats and projects.
formats.description3: The most common event formats currently are:

workshop.title: Workshop
workshop.description: With a strong focus on friendly and welcoming environment, these self-learning, peer-driven workshops try to get people together that want to get into or better at coding.
workshop.who: Everyone who likes to learn coding.
workshop.when: While the introduction workshops often take place on weekends, many smaller workshops also happen during the week.

coLearning.title: Co-learning
coLearning.description: Maybe you don’t know how to get started with coding, got stuck in a tutorial or need help with your project. The co-learning meetup is here for you.
coLearning.who: Everyone who likes to learn or teach coding and wants to meet other learners, or just likes to chat about tech.
coLearning.when: Meeting weekly or bi-weekly on a weekday evening, these groups always have coaches there to help you, while each one just continues on their project in a relaxed and welcoming atmosphere.

codeOfConduct.title: Code of Conduct
codeOfConduct.description: The main goal of all OpenTechSchool events and online meetups is to provide a friendly and welcoming learning environment and to be inclusive to the largest number of participants, with the most varied and diverse backgrounds possible.
codeOfConduct.description2: Before joining our local events or participating in our online communities please make sure you understand and agree to our Code of Conduct. All learners, coaches, organizers and volunteers are required to conform to the Code of Conduct.

contribute.title: Contribute
contribute.description: Thanks to the work of many volunteers OpenTechSchool is able to offer free tech education to a wide range of learners. Volunteers contribute their time and share their knowledge to make OTS events a place where everyone can learn, connect and grow.
contribute.description2: Join the movement by coaching to learners, organising events in your city or offering general support. If you have ideas on how to improve the learning experience, just come and tell us! OpenTechSchool is always looking for individuals who like to give back to the community.

volunteering.title: Become a volunteer

coach.title: Become a coach
coach.description: Coaches help to spread the fun of coding. They are not only supporting learners with the expertise and knowledge, they also try to create a friendly and welcoming environment at the events.
coach.description2: Read more about coaching at our coaching guidelines.

organize.title: Organize a meetup
organize.description: As an organizer you plan and schedule a meetup in your city, promote them and make sure there are enough coaches available.
organize.description2: Read more about how to organize a co-learning meetup.

openChapter.title: Open a new chapter
openChapter.description: If you are interested in organising tech events or regular meetups for the community but your city doesn't have an OTS chapter yet, we can help you getting started.
openChapter.description2: Read more about how to start a chapter.

volunteering.getInTouch: If you are intersted in volunteering work, don't hesitate to contact us even if you are not sure how to contribute yet. Here are a few examples on how to volunteer, but there are so many more!

supporter.title: Become a supporter
supporter.description: If you like what OpenTechSchool is doing, but you can't volunteer, there are other ways to support the initiative.
supporter.sponsor: Maybe you have a space to offer or you want to sponsor the next event. If you are interested in a cooperation please
supporter.membership: Another way to support OpenTechSchool is to become a member of the foundation. By becoming a member you're actively supporting the community with your membership fees.

hero.title: OpenTechSchool Guides
hero.description: We are happy to hear that you would like to get involved in the OTS community.
hero.description2: This page offers guides around how to volunteering as a coach, organizing events or start OpenTechSchool in your city.
hero.howToCity: How to start OpenTechSchool in my city
hero.howToRequest: How to request a meetup or workshop

coaching.title: Coaching guidelines
coaching.intro: You are about to help out at an OpenTechSchool meetup or workshop as a coach. We want to give you a quick introduction of what that means. The focus for the event is to show learners that coding and tech is nothing to be afraid of, but rather a lot of fun!
coaching.notTeaching: Instead of standing infront to teach something, coaches are right there when needed, encourage learners and ensure they having fun doing it.
coaching.friendlyEnv: Smile, make eye contact, be kind and friendly. Look around to see if someone else might be having trouble. Come by once in a while and ask if you can help.
coaching.questions: Get people comfortable asking questions. Give other learners the chance to answer. Respond to questions positively.
coaching.dont: We don't roll our eyes or laugh at questions. We do not debate which programming language, methods or technologies are better.

organizeMeetup.title: Organize an co-learning meetup
organizeMeetup.description: A co-learning meetup is an event aimed at everyone who’s learning to code, develop software, or anything tech-related. This includes both absolute beginners as well as developers who want to acquire new tech skills and get into passionate conversations about it. After all: lifelong, we are all learners!
organizeMeetup.description2: The other purpose of this event is to help build a community around OTS and keep its members engaged, offering a regular event as reference meeting point for learners who want to ask questions or present their latest projects, coaches willing to offer their skills by joining the event’s discussions, and anyone interested in participating in a skill exchange.
organizeMeetup.previousChapters: Learn from previous chapters in your city. What has worked, what didn't?
organizeMeetup.agreement: Make sure the event and its idea is in agreement with our
organizeMeetup.valuesBullet: even though your event may be targeting a certain group of people, it needs to be as open and inclusive as possible
organizeMeetup.valuesBullet2: you have to make sure that the event is enjoyable/accessible at a beginner’s level
organizeMeetup.valuesBullet3: always remember that the Co-learning Meetup ought to give beginners the chance to learn, (hopefully) get answers to their questions, and present what they have created or discovered
organizeMeetup.valuesBullet4: you are responsible for creating a welcoming learning environment, where learners are encouraged to ask questions and nothing is assumed to be “self-explanatory.” State this explicitly at the beginning of the meetup, to embolden the shy people and so everyone attending can help you create this environment.

newChapter.title: How to start OpenTechSchool in my city
newChapter.intro: We won’t lie to you: starting something is always hard. This might not only be hard, but also very frustrating at times. This guide is here for you. You can also contact us when you get stuck and we’ll see how we can help you.
newChapter.teamingUp: Get a team together. Make sure you have people that are:
newChapter.bullet2: already organizing (or organized) some tech events (e.g. meetups, usergroups)
newChapter.bullet3: know how to code and is enthusiast about coaching at a beginner level
newChapter.connect: Something very helpful in getting people to get in touch with each other. OTS can help you out! We already have a Slack where you can get connected.
newChapter.social: Social networks are a great tool to promote your events and get in touch with more tech enthusiasts every day. OTS has its own (global) Facebook and Twitter profiles and in addition to this, we’ll provide a localized OTS Twitter account for your city.
newChapter.previousChapters: Also keep in mind that there might has been a chapter in your city before. It's best to reach out to them and learn about what went well and what didn't. OpenTechSchool can provide you with a list of previous chapters and contacts.

planningMeetup.title: Planning the meetup
planningMeetup.notAlone: Always more fun to not do it alone.

venue.title: Find a venue
venue.description: We suggest trying to get in contact with coworking spaces, hacker spaces, and start-ups that might want to offer their office for an OTS event. Any space that would make a good fit with the OTS network and spirit.

date.title: Find a date
date.findDate: We suggest picking a weeknight (optimally, Tuesday - Friday), starting no later than 19:30 and going on no longer than two hours (break included). Ideally, you would already plan to have the meetup monthly, but this is not mandatory.

attendees.title: Find attendees
attendees.description: Find attendees. We can help! If it doesn’t already exist, we will set up an OTS Meetup account for your city (e.g. meetup.com/opentechschool-yourcity) and you’ll be able to use it to communicate about the meetup and have people join the event.
attendees.description2: Furthermore, we’ll promote the event page through our social media channels, mailing lists, user groups, and communities. Of course we also need you to spread the word and get people to join!

atMeetup.title: At the meetup
atMeetup.description: Be sure to get to the venue at least one hour in advance and with at least another co-organizer, in order to set up the space and the projector, put signs up outside, as well as meet the speakers in advance.
atMeetup.description2: Have a member of the OTS team moderate the event. When everybody is sitting, they should do a quick introduction covering:
atMeetup.bullet3: explain that the event is meant to be especially welcoming for beginners
atMeetup.bullet5: point out the other organizers and coaches
